Coronaviruses were first described as viruses of animals, causing a wide spectrum of diseases that include gastroenteritis of pigs (transmissible gastroenteritis virus and porcine epidemic diarrhea virus), encephalitis in pigs (porcine hemagglutinating encephalomyelitis virus), lethal peritonitis in cats (feline infectious peritonitis virus), and bronchitis in chickens (infectious bronchitis virus).
1 However, their potential to cause disease in humans was not described until the 1960s.
2 Seven human coronaviruses (HCoVs) were identified, the first 2 of which, HCoV-OC43 and HCoV-229E, were isolated from patients with respiratory tract infections.
